conclusion: To determine whether the distance fallen during the 10 to 15 seconds interval is greater than 75 meters or less than 75 meters, we need to analyze the area under the velocity-time graph for that specific time interval.
The graph shows the velocity v (in m/s) as a function of time t (in seconds).
From t = 0 to t = 10 seconds, the velocity increases and reaches a maximum value of approximately 20 m/s.
From t = 10 to t = 15 seconds, the velocity decreases and stabilizes around 10 m/s.
The distance traveled during any time interval is given by the area under the velocity-time graph for that interval.

premise: The distance traveled during any time interval is given by the area under the velocity-time graph for that interval.
conclusion: We need to calculate the area under the curve from t = 10 to t = 15 seconds.
The shape of the curve between t = 10 and t = 15 seconds appears to be roughly a trapezoid.
The height of the trapezoid is the time interval, which is 15 - 10 = 5 seconds.
The two parallel sides (bases) of the trapezoid are the velocities at t = 10 seconds and t = 15 seconds.
At t = 10 seconds, the velocity is approximately 20 m/s.
At t = 15 seconds, the velocity is approximately 10 m/s.
The formula for the area A of a trapezoid is: A = 1/2 × (Base1 + Base2) × Height

premise: The formula for the area A of a trapezoid is: A = 1/2 × (Base1 + Base2) × Height
